unit_learning_outcomes.description: Analyse and describe the way that history is used in different genres of fiction.
Demonstrate an understanding of the place that historical novels have in the public understanding of history.
Demonstrate an ability to form cohesive and well-researched arguments about literary texts, and present these ideas both orally and in writing.
Evaluate both literary and historiographic scholarship on the historical novel.
Explain the development and evolution of the historical novel.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Students will be required to read a series of primary texts (novels, poems, short stories, plays) over the course of the session. Preparation of such readings is in addition to the regular preparation for tutorials.

data.description: Historical fiction is one of the oldest genres of the literary novel, but the past is also used in many different ways in popular mass-market fiction such as romance and fantasy. This unit explores the use of history in narrative forms, including medieval literature, the rise of the novel in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, and the explosion of popular genre fiction in the twentieth century. It looks at how the genre became "feminised" and the role of the novelist Georgette Heyer in creating a new subgenre of historical romance. It explores how fantasy novelists such as George R.R. Martin draw upon medievalism to create strange and compelling worlds in the series A Game of Thrones. Yet the twenty-first century historical novel is not merely entertaining; it can create debates and challenge public perceptions of the past in unsettling ways. Students will also consider how Australian authors have used historical fiction to retell or offer alternative narratives about the nation. By the end of this unit, students will understand how the past informs literary and popular fiction, and why historical fiction can sometimes be considered a form of historiographical interpretation, especially in novels relating to the Second World War and the Holocaust.
